items.title: Citation not found warning when using enumerated lists for References
items.body:
I am trying to use enumerated listst for my references (ideally, I'd like them to be IEEE style, but that's a feature request in the future). My bibliography looks like the following in the reST document:

```
.. bibliography:: refs.bib
   :cited:
   :list: enumerated
```

Unfortunately, when I compile the documents using sphinx (v3.1.2) I get the following warnings:
```
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst:13: WARNING: citation not found: moghimi2011seven
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst:20: WARNING: citation not found: hobbs1997ultrasensitive
```

Strangely, the references list _itself_ displays just fine (I get a properly-cited enumerated list), but each of the individual citations are not replaced with a reference, they are displayed as [hobbs1997ultrasensitive], with no linking, on the document.

My refs.bib file looks like the following:
```
@article{hobbs1997ultrasensitive,
  title={Ultrasensitive laser measurements without tears},
  author={Hobbs, Philip CD},
  journal={Applied optics},
  volume={36},
  number={4},
  pages={903--920},
  year={1997},
  publisher={Optical Society of America}
}
@article{moghimi2011seven,
  title={Seven Steps to Successful Analog-to-Digital Signal Conversion (Noise Calculation for Proper Signal Conditioni  ng)},
  author={Moghimi, Reza},
  journal={Analog Device Services website www. analog. com},
  year={2011},
  publisher={Citeseer}
}
```

items.title: Using same refs.bib for multiple files throws warning in Sphinx
items.body:
Hello, 

Thanks for the awesome extension. I am having an issue where using the same bibliography file _refs.bib_ for mulitple reST files throws an error:

```
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst:56: WARNING: duplicate citation hobbs1997ultrasensitive, other instance in /Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/tia_verification.rst
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst:56: WARNING: duplicate citation moghimi2011seven, other instance in /Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/tia_verification.rst
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/tia_verification.rst:72: WARNING: duplicate citation hobbs1997ultrasensitive, other instance in /Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst
/Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/tia_verification.rst:72: WARNING: duplicate citation moghimi2011seven, other instance in /Users/jordan.e/Google Drive/GTD/PhD/docs/pockels_modulator/system_electronics.rst
WARNING: duplicate label for keys hobbs1997ultrasensitive and hobbs1997ultrasensitive
WARNING: duplicate label for keys moghimi2011seven and moghimi2011seven
```

My bibliography is inserted in both documents in the same way, like this. 
```
.. bibliography:: refs.bib
     :cited:
```

The warnings multiply when I add the bibliography inclusion to more files in the same directory. My understanding is the same refs.bib is often used for multiple files (I have a large BiBTeX database I am building up, and don't want to fragment it unnecessarily if I can avoid doing so).

My refs. bib file contains the following:
```
@article{hobbs1997ultrasensitive,
  title={Ultrasensitive laser measurements without tears},
  author={Hobbs, Philip CD},
  journal={Applied optics},
  volume={36},
```

items.title: How to cite a page number?
items.body:
Normally when I'm writing LaTeX, to reference a specific page number I use the 
```
\cite[54]{smith2004}
```
style discussed in [this answer](https://tex.stackexchange.com/a/292708/90437).  I've been looking through the docs and issues but haven't seen mention of it.

How do I cite a page number with sphinxcontrib-bibtex?

items.title: Citation name is not the same with its bibliography reference
items.body:
Hi!

I have the following problem:
I have used your really excellent package for documenting my [library](https://github.com/ysig/GraKeL), but there appears to be a mismatch of how citation entries are entered between the text and in the bibliography references.

For example [here](https://ysig.github.io/GraKeL/latest/kernels/graphlet_sampling.html) the citations reference name `[SGLLopezB17]` is displayed inside the text as `[sugiyama2017graphkernels]`, which the name used as an identifier for citing it (`\cite{sugiyama2017graphkernels}`).
As I have checked this is the case for everything, so I guess this is a general problem (it is the case for all references).

Do you have a clue of what is going wrong?
If you want to check my documentation files you can see them [here](https://github.com/ysig/GraKeL/tree/0.1a7/doc).

Thanks a lot!

items.title: version the cache data
items.body: As discussed in #185, not doing might result in strange bugs.

items.title: allow multiple footbibliography directives per document
items.body: Those would simply collect the new footcites that preceed it, but that come after the previous footbibliography directive. See discussion in #185.

items.title: better local bibliographies
items.body:
As far as I can tell, this extension works with default settings only if the user abides by two constraints:

1. each citation occurs only once
2. the `.. bibliography::` directive is invoked only once

The project I'm working on ([MNE-Python](https://mne.tools/dev/)) does not follow either constraint: one paper is often cited several times in different files (in multiple docstrings or documentation pages), and our convention is to have a separate `.. bibliography::` for each documentation page where a paper is cited. So for example:

### tutorial_one.py

```
# ... :cite:`foo,bar` ...

...

# .. bibliography:: ../../references.bib
#     :style: unsrt
#
#     desired result:
#     [1] foo...
#     [2] bar...
```


### tutorial_two.py

```
# ... :cite:`qux,foo,baz` ...

...

# .. bibliography:: ../../references.bib
#     :style: unsrt
#
#     desired result:
#     [1] qux...
#     [2] foo...
#     [3] baz...
```

Currently, to support this use case, I have to add and `:keyprefix: a-` to every `.. bibliography::`, and add the key prefix to every citation, and use unique prefixes for each documentation page in which we cite anything. This is a prohibitive amount of work: we have more than 150 unique references, many of them are cited multiple times across files, and we have a lot of documentation pages, so keeping track of which key prefixes are in use is difficult.  Additionally, unless I also specify a `:labelprefix:` in each `.. bibliography::`, I get `WARNING duplicate label for keys a-whatever and b-whatever` at build time (which I can't just ignore, because our documentation CI elevates warnings to errors).

Would you be willing to include a "single-file mode" where references are always resolved locally within the file in which they occur, instead of being pooled across all files?  Or perhaps a `:local:` option that could be added to `bibliography::` that would cause it to only render references that were cited in the current file?

items.title: Examples in docs?
items.body:
Hi, I am interested in using this package. As a potential new user, I really want to see what the output might look like, perhaps with some example citations in this package's own documentation. Another alternative would be to link to some other packages' documentation that are already using this package as examples.

Let me know if you have ideas for how you'd like to add these examples, and I may be able to contribute a PR back!

items.title: Second @manual with same title but different edition not found
items.body:
I have the following bibtex entries:
```
@manual{ABC_R1,
  author       = {xyz},
  title        = {{ABC}},
  edition      = 1,
  year         = {2019},
}
@manual{ABC_R2,
  author       = {xyz},
  title        = {{ABC}},
  edition      = 2,
  year         = {2019},
}
```
In a *.rst file:
```
:cite:`ABC_R1`
:cite:`ABC_R2`
```
This gives the following warnings:
```
*.rst:*: WARNING: citation not found: ABC_R1
```

items.title: phdthesis type
items.body:
I am using the type keyword in @phdthesis to customize the displayed name.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BibTeX#Field_types

The type keyword should be respected if present instead of defaulting to `PhD thesis` for this entry.

[pybtex defines this field](https://bitbucket.org/pybtex-devs/pybtex/src/4bb9a928bb15f701d5ad95979f6d81c2cc2554bf/examples/xampl.bib#lines-314:323)

items.title: How to run parallel build when sphinxcontrib.bibtex is used?
items.body:
My sphinx build take about 20mins to build on Linux. After adding -j auto flag, the time has decreased 4mins and it is great improvement in terms of profermance. However, some page created by the sphinxcontrib-bibtex has broken because sphinxcontrib-bibtex is not parallel safe

Is there any solution to walk around the problem, being able to run my sphinx build in parallel and use the sphinxconrib-bibtex as well.

items.title: Putting LaTeX bibliography where it is defined (same as in HTML)?
items.body:
I find it unfortunate that the LaTeX bibliography ends up at the end of the document, while in HTML output the bibliography/bibliographies end(s) up where it/they is/are defined.

Of course, as stated in the docs (https://sphinxcontrib-bibtex.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage.html#mismatch-between-output-of-html-and-latex-backends), this is a feature of Sphinx and not caused by *sphinxcontrib-bibtex*.

But has anyone ever tried to work around this?

I think this should be possible, but I'm not sure about a few details how this should be done ...

I've come up with a brute force (and quite ugly) work-around, which might serve as a basis for a proper implementation.

First, we have to disable `BibliographyTransform`. If we could change the Sphinx code, we could remove it here: https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/blob/v1.8.2/sphinx/builders/latex/__init__.py#L283

A bit less destructive, we can also monkey-patch it away, I did this in my `conf.py`:

```python
import docutils
import sphinx.builders.latex

class DummyTransform(docutils.transforms.Transform):

    default_priority = 0

    def apply(self):
        pass

sphinx.builders.latex.BibliographyTransform = DummyTransform
```

In a real implementation, we would of course have to find another way to disable this. And this should ideally not interfere with Sphinx native citations.

As a second and last step, I added a bit of raw LaTeX around the bibliography directive in a `.rst` source file:

```rst
References
----------

.. raw:: latex

    \begingroup
    \def\section#1#2{}
    \def\chapter#1#2{}
    \begin{thebibliography}{1234}

.. bibliography:: my-references.bib

.. raw:: latex

    \end{thebibliography}
    \endgroup
```

This works surprisingly well, but of course it would be nice to have this without all the ugly work-around stuff.

Any comments or further ideas?

```

   :style: IEEEtran
```
on which pybtex chokes with
```

    raise PluginNotFound(group, name)
pybtex.plugin.PluginNotFound: plugin pybtex.style.formatting.IEEEtran not found
```

items.title: citations reused in multiple documents not showing up
items.body:
I have 5 documents, which I build individually as pdfs, and together (including them via a toctree) as html.  I include the bibliography in each of the individual documents, and the html works, with the bibliography showing up in the alphabetically last document.  But the individual (pdf) documents do not contain complete bibliographies.

Sometimes, for some of the pdfs, I can get the bibliography to show up by re-running sphinx-build, but for others this does not help.

It looks like I might use key prefixing (https://sphinxcontrib-bibtex.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage.html#section-key-prefixing) except that I need to use the same :cite: key for both the inclusive html document and the separate pdf document.  

Am I missing something?  Or is this not possible with sphinx-build?

items.title: cannot override style templates
items.body:
I added the following to my conf.py file.  If I use the style this works fine, in the sense that the functions I have defined are overridden with my files.  But if I attempt to overwrite any template such as get_article_template nothing changes.  I even tried overriding all the functions in BaseStyle and that did nothing as well.  Is there some reason for this?


[fragment_of_conf_py.txt](https://github.com/mcmtroffaes/sphinxcontrib-bibtex/files/2220008/fragment_of_conf_py.txt)

items.title: question: is it possible to create custom entry types
items.body:
The title says it all really: I see the way to edit the way that standard entries are displayed, but what if I want to introduce a new one, e.g. @patents is non-standard but fairly common.  This is possible in LaTeX, is it possible here?

Thanks in advance, the tool is working well for me in general.

items.title: Standard Sphinx References Cause Warnings
items.body:
My documents have a mixture of bibtex references and standard sphinx references.  The standard sphinx references seem to cause warnings from the bibtex citation engine.  I suppose this is user error of some sort, but I can't seem the find the proper resolution.

Warnings are similar to:

>WARNING: could not relabel citation [Rusu2008]
> WARNING: could not relabel citation [Zhang2003]
> WARNING: could not relabel citation reference [Mongus2012]
> WARNING: could not relabel citation reference [Zhang2003]

items.title: Strange format of the generated bibliography list
items.body:
I am attempting to generate citations for our project using sphinx v1.7.5 [sphinx_bootstrap_theme "yeti"](https://bootswatch.com/yeti/). 
```
.. bibliography:: source/_static/references.bib
   :style: alpha
   :cited:
```
The rendering of the generated bibliography list seems a little odd:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7359284/42296258-7114511c-7fa8-11e8-81ee-84624247ad69.png)
Each entry of the bibliography is rendered as a table and the citation key is transparent. Not sure if this is due to the bootstrap theme "yeti" I am using as the same formatting happens when I switch to other bootstrap themes. 
If I change the type of list used for rendering the bibliography  to a bullet list. It renders just fine:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7359284/42296339-9402e9c6-7fa9-11e8-8ac3-d450cf0faea2.png)

items.title: Question: Link for BibTeX citation for each entry
items.body:
In the displayed bibliography (html), I would like to have a link appended to each reference, where people can copy the original BiBTeX entry for citing the corresponding publication in their own LaTeX document. How could this be done?

One of my ideas was to generate separate .bib files for each reference during the building process and provide a static link to them in the bibliography. Is this sensible?

items.title: Using latexcodec in sphinxcontrib-bibtex is no longer necessary
items.body:
Hi,

sphinxcontrib-bibtex [implicitly uses latexcodec](https://github.com/mcmtroffaes/sphinxcontrib-bibtex/blob/8f72f9897a0324c797b742c551be3d263abb1e2a/sphinxcontrib/bibtex/directives.py#L122) to decode `.bib` files. This is no longer necessary, because Pybtex already uses latexcodec internally since version 0.20.

Doing the decoding on the Pybtex side allows to decode the contents of individual entry fields instead of decoding the whole `.bib` file. This is generally more robust and fixes some parsing problems.

Please just pass the docutils' `input_encoding` without the `"latex+"` prefix to `bibtex.Parser()`.

Thanks!

items.title: Google Scholar labels not working
items.body:
Hello,

I tried the minimal example with a Bibtex reference generated by Google Scholar:

@article{srivastava2014dropout,
  title={Dropout: a simple way to prevent neural networks from overfitting.},
  author={Srivastava, Nitish and Hinton, Geoffrey E and Krizhevsky, Alex and Sutskever, Ilya and Salakhutdinov, Ruslan},
  journal={Journal of Machine Learning Research},
  volume={15},
  number={1},
  pages={1929--1958},
  year={2014}
}

And citing like:

:cite:`srivastava2014dropout`

.. bibliography:: refs.bib
  :style: unsrt

And it just ignores the citation. How do I fix it without having to change all my references generated by Google Scholar?

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Reference not found when author/year/title are duplicate
items.body: I was testing something else and created a bogus .bib file where I just copied the same item twice, changing its label. Then I cite the two labels in the text (default style) and I got `WARNING: citation not found: ECP:10`. It turns out if I modify the author, title or year (but not volume, page or other elements) this is solved. I guess this has to do with automatic label generation, probably in pybtex, but it should be possible to have bibliography items with same author/year/title and different bibtex labels.

items.title: warning about Directive
items.body:
Noticed after moving to sphinx >= 1.6.1

.. code-block::
  
  RemovedInSphinx17Warning: sphinx.util.compat.Directive is deprecated and will be removed in Sphinx 
  1.7, please use the standard library version instead.
    from sphinx.util.compat import Directive

In directives.py, remove the line:
from sphinx.util.compat import Directive

and import Directive too from docutils as:
from docutils.parsers.rst import Directive, directives

items.title: Mathmode support
items.body:
I'm not sure to which extent this is `sphinxcontrib-bibtex` issue but it would be nice to support mathmode in bibliography entries. To reproduce the current behaviour, use this patch
```
diff --git a/test/latex_refs/test.bib b/test/latex_refs/test.bib
index 2bcab4a..b5879fa 100644
--- a/test/latex_refs/test.bib
+++ b/test/latex_refs/test.bib
@@ -1,6 +1,6 @@
 @InCollection{1657:huygens,
   author =      {Christiaan Huygens},
-  title =       {De Ratiociniis in Ludo Ale{\ae}},
+  title =       {De Ratiociniis in Ludo Ale{\ae} $\pi = 3$},
   booktitle =   {Exercitationum Mathematicarum Libri Quinque: Quibus accedit {C}hristiani {H}ugenii Tractatus de Ratiociniis in Ale{\ae} Ludo},
   pages =       {517--524},
   publisher = {Ex officina Johannis Elsevirii},
```

and run
```
cd test/latex_refs
sphinx-build -M latex "." "_build"
grep \\$ _build/latex/test.tex
```

The output is
```
Christiaan Huygens. De ratiociniis in ludo aleæ \$\textbackslash{}pi = 3\$. In Franciscus á Schooten, editor, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Exercitationum Mathematicarum Libri Quinque: Quibus accedit Christiani Hugenii Tractatus de Ratiociniis in Aleæ Ludo}, pages 517\textendash{}524. Ex officina Johannis Elsevirii, Lugd. Batav., 1657.
```

Next step would be to on MathJax support in html output.

items.title: Compilation issues with Sphinxcontrib-bibtex
items.body:
Hi,

I'm having issues with the compilation of my project using sphinxcontrib-bibtex. Basically, the compilation never compile the bibliography the first time. I have errors of the type `citation not found` on several citations even if it seems that my bibtex file seems fine. Even stranger, I need to modify the `conf.py` file in Sphinx, in order to force another compilation that end-up with a successful compilation including the bibliography. At first I thought it was related to ReadTheDocs. Unfortunately, the problem seems somewhere else, that's why I'm asking some help here.

For people who would like to give it a try, I would

- issue open on ReadTheDoc project: rtfd/readthedocs.org#2601
- My project having the issue on Github: [Auditory Motion Perception][l1]
- A build on read the docs: [#4923632][l2]

I can provide as well the output locally as I have the same issue if people are interested in.

[l1]: https://github.com/mattberjon/auditory-motion-perception
[l2]: https://readthedocs.org/projects/auditory-motion-perception/builds/4923632/

FAIL: test_latex_refs.test_latex_refs
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/nose/case.py", line 197, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sphinx_testing/util.py", line 142, in decorator

    assert re.search('\\hyperref\[contents:huygens\]', output)

Changing these lines in test/test_latex_refs.py:

    assert re.search('\\hyperref\[contents:huygens\]', output)
    assert re.search('\\label{contents:huygens}', output)

to this:

    assert re.search('\\hyperref\[\\\\detokenize{contents:huygens}\]', output)
    assert re.search('\\label{\\\\detokenize{contents:huygens}}', output)

fixes the issue, but is wrong for earlier versions of sphinx.

items.title: reference etiquette question
items.body:
I have some projects they look like this in structure:

/docs
/docs/ref.bib   **[inside I might have ref1, ref 2- -> this file is the only .bib file in the /docs and contains all references**]

/examples/set/test1/file1.rst   [**where I talk about ref1 and ref2**]
/examples/set/test1/file2.rst
...
/examples/set10/file30.rst  [ **where I might randomly want to talk about ref1 and ref2 without knowing how    many times I talked about it in the past** ]
So, the Key Prefixing talked about [here](https://sphinxcontrib-bibtex.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage.html#roles-and-directives) would not be favorable. 

I also want to avoid putting reference files (.bib) throughout the documentation in these data sets. I would like one main reference file that will be my bibliography for the project. But, it would still be nice to cite the references as well on the bottom of the pages that they appear on. 

I know this may be asking for a lot, because I have done my due diligence here and it does not seem like my idea of setting this thing up is going to work. Is that correct? Any suggestions are more than welcome.

Thanks!

items.title: Author name abbreviation
items.body:
When running the Sphinx example/test:
https://github.com/mcmtroffaes/sphinxcontrib-bibtex/tree/develop/test/sphinx
most author names are abbreviated as expected, but not all, especially not
```
@ARTICLE{Astrom2005,
  author = {{\AA}str{\"o}m, Karl J. and Klein, Richard E. and Lennartsson, Anders},
```
With some small changes it is abbreviated:
```
@ARTICLE{Astrom2005,
  author = {Astr\"om, Karl J. and Klein, Richard E. and Lennartsson, Anders},
```
So, using `\"o` is acceptable, but using `{\"o}` breaks the abbreviation.
I can fix this on my side, but I do not know what to do about the `{\AA}`.
Any suggestions? Thanks.

items.title: Memory usage
items.body:
I'm seeing large memory usage on docs with a large bibliography file. Memory usage continues to balloon after parsing completes on the bibliography file -- memory usage peaks around 7.5G

This seems like leaky behavior to me, though I haven't had much luck tracking things down with `gdb`. I'm also not familiar enough with bibtex to say that this isn't normal behavior, though that seems unlikely.

**Edit: found a hack fix and the likely cause, but not sure of the proper fix**

I was able to get a full pass of the doc build in when I truncated the bibliography to <100 entries -- it looks like excessive copying is the issue:
https://gist.github.com/agjohnson/c1ebef16c11d8d22204af9f7edd77c85#file-bibtex-profile-L28-L34

Inspecting the `pybtex.database.Entry` object, it has a copy of the original bibliography entries (!!). This explains the egregious memory consumption. The hack fix to reduce memory usage and parse the full list was to null out `entry.collection` before it was copied here:
https://github.com/mcmtroffaes/sphinxcontrib-bibtex/blob/develop/sphinxcontrib/bibtex/cache.py#L312-L314

I didn't test what side-effects this had.

items.body:
Using Sphinx 1.4.1 with sphinxcontrib-bibtex 0.3.3 on Windows 10 to produce a PDF, every bibitem in the tex file exists two times. Or rather, the full bibliography exists twice. 
Not sure whether this is a bug or if I am doing something wrong.
When compiling the same project on Linux, I get the same behavior.

Is the following issue related?
https://github.com/sphinx-doc/sphinx/issues/2412

items.title: hyperlink from :cite: to citation in HTML?
items.body:
I'm trying to use sphinxcontrib-bibtex to replace natbib, so apologies if this is not an Issue.  I'm using sphinxcontrib-bibtex from the current github master and sphinx 1.3.1.

I'd like to have the citation give a cross-reference and hyperlink to the bibliography entry in the HTML version documentation.  the natbib package I was surprised this doesn't happen -- could I be doing something wrong?    The bibliography file is being parsed and displayed correctly (and, very nicely, BTW!), and the citation is displayed in the place of the `:cite:` directive, but it is not a hyperlink.

I don't actually see such a cross-reference in any of the examples.   If this is not already implemented, and I'm simply doing something silly, would this be a desirable feature for sphinxcontrib-bibtex?

items.title: The sphinxcontrib.bibtex extension is not safe for parallel reading
items.body: Can it be made safe?

items.title: `:cite:` inside a figure caption fails the latexpdf output
items.body:
When `:cite:` is used inside a figure caption, the following error message shows for the latexpdf output:

```
Incomplete \iffalse; ; all text was ignored after line xxx
```

I figured out the reason---`\phantomsection` cannot be used in a caption. Once I removed phantomsection, the compilation passed. Is there any reason we use phantomsection here?

items.title: specify global options
items.body:
Every time I want to use bibliography, I have to type:

```
.. bibliography:: refs.bib
    :style: unsrt
```

Is there any way to specify this global style in `conf.py`? Thanks!

items.title: Local bibliography KeyPrefix: duplicated citation in the latexpdf output
items.body: While the option `:keyprefix:` solves the problem for HTML output of local bibliography, the pdf output still generates duplicated reference entries. Is there any way to fix this? Thanks!

items.title: Support docstring local bibliographies
items.body:
How difficult would this be to implement. I think you already mentioned something about this in #52. It would be really nice to have this feature, since a method/function could in principle refer to some articles. 
The current behaviour is to hyperlink the citation in the same document in which bibliography it has been cited first. This way your browser will jump from the current docstring to a method/function, where this has been cited first, which is somehow confusing.

Maybe this is already supported or literally impossible due to some sphinx specific design issues? Sorry I'm fairly new to this extension...
Thank you very much!

items.title: Formatting inside a reference entry
Empty lines in bib file make Pybtex choke
items.body:
Hi, thank you for the [hint with the "latex" encoding](https://code.launchpad.net/~jorrit83/pybtex/mduc/+merge/234975/comments/574760). I can see that this project also processes the bib file in a similar way. 

The substitution of Latex code to unicode causes a problem if the bib file contains empty lines. Those get translated to the `\par` command, which cannot be digested by Pybtex. This behaviour is OK, because the initial processing step creates an invalid bibtex file.

Consider the following example from the homepage:

```
import StringIO
import pybtex.database.input.bibtex
import pybtex.plugin
import latexcodec

# Prepare the data
raw = """@Book{1985:lindley,
  author =    {D. L{\\`i}ndley},
  title =     {Making Decisions},

  publisher = {Wiley},
  year =      {1985},
  edition =   {2nd},
}"""

ascii_obj = raw.decode('ascii')
latex_obj = raw.decode('latex+ascii')
ascii_buf = StringIO.StringIO(ascii_obj)
latex_buf = StringIO.StringIO(latex_obj)

# Remove lines
raw   = '\n'.join([l.strip() for l in raw.splitlines() if l.strip()])
ascii_obj_clean = raw.decode('ascii')
latex_obj_clean = raw.decode('latex+ascii')
ascii_buf_clean = StringIO.StringIO(ascii_obj_clean)
latex_buf_clean = StringIO.StringIO(latex_obj_clean)

# Prepare iteration
objs = [ ascii_obj_clean, latex_obj_clean, ascii_obj, latex_obj ]
bufs = [ ascii_buf_clean, latex_buf_clean, ascii_buf, latex_buf ]

# Prepare Pybtex
style = pybtex.plugin.find_plugin('pybtex.style.formatting', 'plain')()
backend = pybtex.plugin.find_plugin('pybtex.backends', 'plaintext')()

for buf in bufs:
    print("")
    print(buf.getvalue())
    parser = pybtex.database.input.bibtex.Parser()
    data = parser.parse_stream(buf)
    biblio = style.format_bibliography(data)
    stream = StringIO.StringIO()
    backend.write_to_stream(biblio, stream)
    contents = stream.getvalue()
    stream.close()
    print(contents)
```

Maybe you could add a preprocessing step to remove empty lines. Alternatively, you could filter out the `\par` commands. I had a look at your code, but it was not straight forward to add this functionality.

items.title: avoid duplicate labels by global invokation of pybtex on all bibliographies from all documents at once
items.body:
Suggested by @bk322 in issue #62.

This would create a dependency between all documents that have citations or bibliographies, so probably this should not be the default. However, we could add a switch that enables this.

items.title: numbering and multiple item problem when citing from multiple documents
items.body: Reported by @bk322 - forked from issue #52

items.title: multiple citation keys within a single :cite:
items.body:
I'd expected a 

```
:cite:`one:1989,two:1999,three:1988`
```

to give multiple citations. Aren't they supported?

items.title: Multiple bibliographies?
items.body:
I have a sphinx doc, and I'd like several pages to have a bibliography. However, each bibliography call

```
.. bibliography:: _static/bib/refs.bib
```

produces all references of the sphinx doc, while I want it to insert just the citations I referenced in the current rst page.
Can this be done?

items.title: \hyperref{path/to/file:anchor}
items.body:
Hi, 

I'm not sure this is exactly the place to ask, but I'll take a shot. 

While using `:cite:` and generating pdf, the `\href` generated contain extra path to file location making latex not resolve the reference eg : 

```
\hyperref[parts/part1:iwabuchi2010]{IT10}
```

instead of 

```
\hyperref[iwabuchi2010]{IT10}
```

Any clue on how I can circumvent that ?

Thanks.

items.title: local bibliographies
items.body:
Reported over email by @chebee7i

> I've played
> briefly with your package, and the biggest issue I ran into is that it seems
> to be painful to have local bibliographies per docstring or rst file.
> 
> That is, if I put:
> 
> .. bibliography:: ../references.bib
>    :cited:
> 
> at the end of a docstring or ReST file, then it is including all cited
> references throughout all docstrings and ReST files.  I've seen the stuff
> for filtrations, but this is really a lot of work.

Yes, a filter just for local stuff would seem highly inappropriate...

> So is it easy to have :local: citations only? I still want to construct a
> global bibliography, but I'd like to be able to have many different
> docstrings cite the same reference, possibly multiple times, and have local
> and global bibliographies.

That sounds like an attractive feature - I'll look into it! Per document is probably quite easy to implement. Per docstring seems tricky - I'd have to look into Sphinx's autodoc extension to see if I can somehow hook into it.

Aside, an obvious problem with multiple bibliographies is: sphinx does not allow duplicate citations (and currently I cannot easily work around that...), so where should citations point to (this is the same in latex...)? But you could have a local citation list with normal global citations, or the other way around.

items.title: support inline bibtex entries similar to bibentry
items.body: See http://stefaanlippens.net/bibentry

items.title: support natbib style citation roles
items.body: ... like citet, citep and so on. See https://bitbucket.org/wnielson/sphinx-natbib

items.title: LaTeX output generates an extra "References" title whilst html output does not
items.body:
Reported on stackoverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16776628/sphinxcontrib-bibtex-problems-when-making-latexpdf-document

To fix discrepancies between html and latex output, we need to fix the latex writer to use the bibtopic package instead (not sure if upstream would accept this... we can sure try).

items.title: Why wrong label reference at :cite: expansion?
items.body:
Hi,

I've tried unsuccessfullyto use `:cite:` together with `.. bibliography::`, both very close together and in different files. I also tried all things mentioned in the  [troubleshooting](http://sphinxcontrib-bibtex.readthedocs.org/en/latest/usage.html#unresolved-citations-across-documents) chapter.

I also looked into the generated `.tex` file and see that the problem is mainly, that the refs that expand the `:cite:` block are actually referencing the name I was giving in the bibtex element, while the `\bibitem` references `1`. This is like 2 times painful, because I would live with the references to `1` but I am actually more happy if the code is able to reference my names instead of numbers.

Am I doing something completely wrong here? Because the intended thing that this project should do doesn't work at all. I think if this would really be a bug someone would have already fixed it. But on the other hand it doesn't work even if I create a complete new project with a very simple and probably error free setup. A little confused here.
## Details

Here is what I am using:

test.rst contains:

```
Test
====

This is a test text :cite:`testlabel` which references a test element.

 .. bibliography:: test.bib
```

And test.bib contains:

```
@misc {testlabel,
     title="a Test",
     author="me",
     year="2013",}
```

items.title: Document how to create new custom styles from the standard pybtex unsrt style.
items.body: forked from issue #25

items.title: Include internet link?
items.body: Is there a way bibtex can also include an Internet link from a bib file to a reference entry? I guess this should be possible by creating custom style, or modifying plain style.

items.title: Sphinx [source] labels trigger a lot of warnings.
items.body: I'm using citations in a project with a lot of source code.  The [source] links generated by Sphinx seem to trigger label translations.  I've got a small patch to fix the problem, although the fix is not elegant: it just suppresses the warnings in that case.

items.title: Sort references in the order they are cited
items.body:
I am using your plugin to write my dissertation. I would like the numbering of the citations to start from [1] and continue as [2], [3], ..., in the order that I cite it in the text. Currently, the references are sorted in some way, and so in my case the citations start as [26], [23], [24], [32], [18], ...

Is there any way to fix this?

items.title: each new bibliography starts counting at 0 again
items.body: this creates conflicts in latex output as well as strangeness in html output

items.title: no split bibliographies in latex output
items.body:
unlike html output, the latex output, puts the citations together on one big chunk at the end,

so its not possible to put different bibliographies in with different titles

items.title: Link to PDF, PS or DVI using BibTeX optional field.
items.body:
I have an enhancement request, please.  I usually have PDF copies of papers that I cite.  I would love to be able to put an optional BibTeX field

  `pdffile = {../papers/Aristotle_2011_DeepThoughts.pdf}`

into my .bib files and trigger a link to the paper itself.  Perhaps the link could be from the title or an icon in the citation list entry of  the paper.  In effect, each citation would have a :download:`Deep Thoughts <../papers/Aristotle_2011_DeepThoughts.pdf>` entry.

I've been digging through the transform.py code and it's not obvious to me how to do this, I see code for URL processing but wasn't able to trigger it.  If it's obvious to you and a quick fix, I would really appreciate the feature.  If it's lots of work for you too, let me know and I'll see if I can work through the details.

Thanks
-- Simon

items.title: Can't jump back from a bib item to the corresponding cite.
items.body:
It's far beyond my expectation that it provides a feature the we can jump from a citation to the bibitem back and forth.

But I find there is a bug that I can't jump back from a bib item to the corresponding cite.

I notice the href property of the bititem node is right, but there is no corresponding id property in the cite node.

I think only a minor modification is needed, which would cost you only 5 miniutes :-)

items.title: generate \cite and \bibliography commands for LaTeX
items.body:
Currently, \hyperref, and actual text, are generated, and bibtex is entirely circumvented. This is not useful in case the generated LaTeX is to be processed further e.g. by relatex:

http://people.mbi.ucla.edu/leec/docs/relatex/index.html

Such tools typically expect actual \cite and \bibliography commands, and rely on LaTeX to resolve citations, and on BibTeX to generate the entries.

(privately reported by Chen Houwu)

items.title: Generated HTML bibliography not alphabetically ordered, instead presented as parsed
items.body:
Hi there,

I really like you plugin and want to use it for my Sphinx site, but the trouble is that the generated HTML bibliography is not alphabetically ordered, but instead reflects the order in which the items have been entered into the bib-file. Should this not be addressed?

Cheers,
Eric

items.title: citations not always found
items.body:
(forked from issue #2)

When a citation occurs in a file that is parsed before the file with the corresponding bibliography directive is parsed, that citation will not be resolved. A temporary workaround for this problem is to ensure that your bibliography resides in a file that is alphabetically last.

Implementation note: the cause of this problem is that docutils/sphinx applies its transforms immediately after initial parsing of each doctree, instead of waiting until all initial doctrees are constructed?

items.title: alpha style labels
items.body: The current numbered style clashes with Sphinx's footnotes, so perhaps we should use alpha style labels instead.

items.title: In text citation format
items.body:
With the default settings the inline citations in the html are formatted as `[i]` where i is a number. Sphinx footnotes also use this inline naming convention. So it is possible to have something like "In Watson's latest paper [1], he explained stuff [1]" where the first [1] is a citation to a external reference and the second one is a footnote at the bottom of the page. This potentially confusing.

It would be preferable to have options for what is displayed inline for the citations like [Author, year] or the bibtex key.

items.title: Handling patent entries
items.body:
I have some @patents in my bib database. I get this exception from pybtex:

``` pytb
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pybtex/style/formatting/__init__.py", line 56, in format_entries
    f = getattr(self, "format_" + entry.type)
AttributeError: 'Style' object has no attribute 'format_patent'
```

Looks like the pybtex.style.formatting.unsrt.Style class doesn't handle that for some reason.

I can post this to pybtex instead, but I saw that you've been pushing to pybtex too.

items.title: :encoding: option is broken
items.body:
Currently, if :encoding: is used, the latex codec does not do its job to transform special latex commands (such as \AA) into unicode.

(forked from issue #2)

items.title: []_ style citations do not result in a bibliography entry being added
items.body:
It would be useful if users could simply use regular []_ style citations (provided that the key does not contain any illegal characters for regular citations), instead of :cite: style citations.

(forked from issue #2)

items.title: Labels are not being collected for large project.
items.body:
Matthias,

This is a follow up to the email I sent. I was able to setup a new sphinx project and use my .bib file to properly generate citations with no errors, but when I attempt to use your extension with my actual project it seems the bib labels are not being collected properly.

If you clone: https://github.com/moorepants/dissertation/tree/sphinxcontrib-bibtex

I've only used your `:cite:` directive in the eom.rst file. The references should appear in references.rst.

I did:

``` console
mkdir dissertation
cd dissertation
git init
git remote add -t sphinxcontrib-bibtex -f origin git://github.com/moorepants/dissertation.git
git checkout sphinxcontrib-bibtex
```

to avoid cloning the gh-pages branch which is large.

Now run:

``` console
make html
```

You will get a ton of warnings and errors due to the missing figures, tables and such, but it should compile.

This exception should occur:

``` python
  File "/home/moorepants/src/sphinxcontrib-bibtex/sphinxcontrib/bibtex/__init__.py", line 80, in process_citation_references
    '[' + app.env.bibtex_citation_label[label] + ']')
KeyError: u'Zytveld1975'
```

If you run sphinx with the `-P` flag you can see that `app.env.bibtex_citation_label` is an empty dictionary.

items.title: Problem when using bibtex with tinker
items.body:
Hello,

I'm using tinker ( http://tinkerer.me/ ) together with sphinxcontrib-bibtex and have a strange error when trying to compile a rst document :
# Sphinx version: 1.1.3
# Python version: 2.6.1
# Docutils version: 0.9.1 release
# Jinja2 version: 2.6

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/cmdline.py", line 189, in main
    app.build(force_all, filenames)
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/application.py", line 204, in build
    self.builder.build_update()
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/builders/**init**.py", line 196, in build_update
    'out of date' % len(to_build))
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/builders/**init**.py", line 252, in build
    self.write(docnames, list(updated_docnames), method)
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/builders/**init**.py", line 291, in write
    doctree = self.env.get_and_resolve_doctree(docname, self)
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/environment.py", line 1233, in get_and_resolve_doctree
    self.resolve_references(doctree, docname, builder)
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/environment.py", line 1489, in resolve_references
    builder.app.emit('doctree-resolved', doctree, fromdocname)
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/Sphinx-1.1.3-py2.6.egg/sphinx/application.py", line 314, in emit
    results.append(callback(self, *args))
  File "/Users/obo/Library/Python/2.6/site-packages/sphinxcontrib/bibtex/**init**.py", line 80, in process_citation_references
    '[' + app.env.bibtex_citation_label[label] + ']')
KeyError: u'2011:BabikerIPv6'
~

Here is an extract of the document :

In :cite:`2011:BabikerIPv6`, google engineers explain the issues that they faced when migrating the enterprise networks of google premisses to support IPv6. Surprisingly, one of the main bottleneck in this migration was the support of IPv6 on the transparent proxies that they use to accelerate web access.

In :cite:`2012:TsouExploring`, researchers and network administrators from FutureWei report their experience in adding IPv6 connectivity to their network. The report is short on enabling IPv6, but discusses more recent solutions that are being developed within the IETF.

Another interesting viewpoint is the one discussed in :rfc:`6585`. In this RFC, Jari Arkko and Ari Keranen report all the issues that they faced while running an IPv6 only network in their lab and using it on a daily basis to access the Internet which is still mainly IPv4.

.. bibliography:: ../../../biblio.bib

and the bibtex file

@InProceedings{2011:BabikerIPv6,
  author =   {H. Babiker and I. Nikolova and K. Chittimaneni},
  title =    {Deploying IPv6 in the Google Enterprise Network.  Lessons learned.},
  booktitle = {USENIX LISA 2011},
  year =     2011,
  note = {\url{http://static.usenix.org/events/lisa11/tech/full_papers/Babiker.pdf}} }
